comments.text:
Maybe it's because in London there are a lot of 'lower class' people who 
are from black backgrounds, whereas the footage from Liverpool clearly 
shows mostly white rioters because further north 'lower class' people tend 
to be from white backgrounds. I don't think people were looting 'because 
they're black'. I think the people looted because they don't feel connected 
to society, they don't feel equal, there is an 'us and them' mentality 
amongst young, lower class people in this society, and police harassment is 
a very real problem in these communities. There is a mistrust of the entire 
'system'. And that often includes resentment for anything from police, to 
people who they feel have more money than them. The UK has some real class 
issues that we need to deal with. These estates and apartment blocks that 
these people come from are part of the problem. This country is not 
integrated at all. If you're from a poorer background, you go and live over 
there in that shitty block of flats, but if you were brought up in a middle 
class family then you can live over there on that friendly street of semi 
detached 5 bedroomed houses with mid range vehicles on every driveway. It's 
crazy that in our country you can usually tell which 'class' someone is 
from (and therefore what type of accommodation they live in, how much they 
earn, etc) just by hearing their accent. It's crazy. We are so segregated 
in terms of race and wealth that each section of society has formed their 
own accent. I wonder if this country would allow a lower class Liverpudlian 
to run for prime minister. I highly doubt it. Ah sorry I'm ranting. I guess 
we'll never truly understand the reasons why the riots happened but I think 
in part much of it was just seizing an opportunity to take things that you 
really want and in some cases can't afford. The whole thing was probably 
spurred by a general resentment and feeling of exclusion from the rest of 
society. 'Fuck everyone else, these people have never done anything good 
for me so I'll take what I want.' But it certainly isn't because 'their all 
black'. That was an incredibly judgemental and ignorant thing to say.
Wikipedia has a good article on the riots and highlights that "The ethnic 
makeup of the rioters varied in different cities: 76% of those arrested in 
Manchester were white, while 29% were white and 39% black in London, and 
the West Midlands was the only area where more than 6% were Asian."

captions.text: [DIAL-UP SOUND]

-It was on Monday, the 8th of
August, 2011, that Britain's
superstructure collapsed.

By midnight, it was clear that
the police and the government
had lost control.

For one night, at least,
delinquent anarchy had proved

more powerful than fellowship
and bureaucracy.

On Monday afternoon, with shops
boarded up, it was clear

that all London needed to
explode was a spark.
And this was it.

At the narrows at the end of
Mare Street in Hackney, three
police vans swerved to a stop.

About 10 policemen
rushed two men.

A crowd quickly formed, exciting
themselves and
freaking out the police.

Soon there were two groups, and
bricks were being thrown.
[SHOUTING]

-A gridlock of cop
cars and rioters
grew beneath the bridge.

And soon there was a running
battle up Mare Street.
-Oh shit.
[SHOUTING]

-The crowd was split into two,
half of whom were chased up

Morning Lane, where they
broke into Tesco's.

"Missile up," they shouted while
pulling out Coke cans

and bottled water and charging
towards the cops.
[SHOUTING]

-The rest of the crowd were
moved up Mare Street.

And that's when everything
started to go crazy.

[SHOUTING, BREAKING
GLASS, SIRENS]

-As the daylight robbery turned
into midnight chaos, it

became increasingly dangerous to
be seen on the street with

a camera, or just without
any bag of swag.

We made our way to Kingsland
Road, though, where we heard

that the local Turks had driven
the rioters off by

running down the street with
blades and weapons.
